Some of us have been saying winning or lossing based on RNG is bad for a competive game and even Doublelift has said it is a problem to some degree.

The counter arguments tend to be:

1) if you are really that much better it doesn't matter which sounds great until you get triple crited by a Trynda at level 2 and he then to snowballs out of control because RNG was on his side.

2) the general effective damage in theory is the same. Which actually is more of a argument against it since it is no longer RNG if it is changed to a % of total AD boost.

> Some of us have been saying winning or lossing based on RNG is bad for a competive game and even Doublelift has said it is a problem to some degree.

Playing devil's advocate here, but DOTA2 has pseudo-random crit *and* pseudo-random dodge, though. And DOTA2 is certainly not doing bad for itself, if TI is any indication of the absolutely stupidly high prize pool they're able to award. So that at least shows that there are games in which RNG in a competitive environment doesn't immediately indicate the game is problematic.

World of Tanks is a(n) (fledgling) e-sport that relies completely on RNG to decide whether a shot lands *and if it does, whether it does damage* **and if it does, how much damage.** But there are people playing it competitively, so it indicates that the RNG is acknowledged but accepted.

---
Of course, I think Ashe has got a good argument for how ADCs whose damage output isn't subject to RNG can look like, while still building Crit and Attack Speed. Certainly sucks when some battles come down to "I didn't crit enough" *more* than "My damage wasn't sufficient" (which is only a *direct result* of the former).

Actually, given that this conversation is about crit and stuff, BKB is absolutely worthless - about all it's going to give you against attack-based stuff is the 200 health from the strength and immunity to _a few_ attack abilities.

You almost always see it, though, because as much as there's stuff that goes through BKB there's still tons of stuff that don't, and being able to DPS or especially channel without being interrupted can be such a big deal.

Given that Critical Strike is pseudo-RNG and controlled by algorithms it baffles me that Riot doesn't just disallow back-to-back criticals below a certain Critical Chance threshold.

I'd really hate to see Critical Strike be replaced by something as bland as % AD boost. I was here for the days of Bloodthirster rush, where whoever farmed slightly better or got a better gank got ahead and stayed ahead. AD DPS *needs* something besides bonus flat damage on every hit or it is just completely oppressive (see: everyone complaining about Marksmen that just build AD and flat Armor Penetration). 

Critical Strike does need some definite changes: Crit runes have to go, and Critical Chance should really be removed from component items and only added to completed items (similar to how Riot removed Spellvamp from Revolver but let Gunblade keep its omnivamp passive). For champions meant to rely on Crit I'd like to see more kits with abilities that interact with Crits (i.e. do something cool when you Crit) but not just giving Critical Chance for nothing (i.e. Tryndamere needs a rework).

I think the problem most people have is that while yes, it is psuedo-random (which is great as the player critting) it's still random (which has the potential to be worse for the person you're playing against). Psuedo-random RNG actually hurts this game in a lot of ways because I don't believe that they implemented it as harshly as they should have - in DotA2 for example, you have a LOWER than average chance to crit on your first attack but it increases with every hit, with the first critical taking you to the reduced first rate. With the number of double/triple crits that I see happen in LoL I have a hard time believing this is the case. It also really sucks because psuedo-random RNG at anything higher than 50% crit basically guarantees every other auto crits, which seems nice until you get 3-4 in a row thanks to the RNG that's mixed in there.

Basically, in a vacuum where everyone only ever gets like 25% crit chance crit doesn't need any changes, but with higher crit values psuedo-random RNG actually starts to work against "health" at least from a feel perspective (because it can create multiple crits in a row, as LoL's RNG doesn't seem to force non-crits after a crit appropriately based on crit chance).

Why doesn't DotA remove the RNG entirely if they want crit chance to stack up?

Yeah you'll see triple-quadra crits in LoL ... you'll never notice if you didn't get crit.

Because true RNG means that a 20% chance to occur means it's just as likely for something to happen 10 times in a row than it is to never occur in a set of 10 triggers.

Through PRNG, it assures that on a string of really bad luck, an action will be forced to occur when the true chance reached 100%. Additionally, it reduces ( but doesn't nullify ) the chance for a low-chance proc to occur three times in a row, because you're actually working with a far lower chance.

Plus there's the fact that randomness doesn't feel random to us. Critting 5 times in a row might seem to fit 10% crit chance because over a hundred attacks, that was half of our crits, but it certainly doesn't _seem_ like it's actually 10% when it happens.

These changes would make the items worse for their intended users and possibly better for marksmen that are abusing it.

* Stacking flat penetration is supposed to be a good stat for assassins, as they are supposed to target those that will not stack armor items.
* Increasing time for the passive to trigger after applied helps marksmen (who can continue to attack, lowering the target's health, thus increasing the passive trigger damage) more than assassins (who generally pop in, drop a bunch of spells and an auto or two, and pop out)
* Changing the passive damage to magic might help assassins compared to marksman slightly if they are running the mixed flat pen mastery, which is now rare for marksmen, but it does hurt the assassins use of it as they have less magic penetration than armor penetration.
* Increasing the passive cooldown timer probably hurts assassins more than marksmen.  Assassins are more likely to use this as an "extra skill" in their combos and will probably end up somewhat balanced around this item.  Marksmen, however, get the item for the stats more than the passive and will continue to do the bulk of their damage via consistent autos, even if the passive cooldown is increased.

Ok, so it seems like we're moving the discussion off Duskblade in particular and onto assassin vs marksman itemization overall.

Your post included a glut of items, many of which will never be considered by Marksmen or the AD/physical Assassins that are the intended buyers of Duskblade, so I'll ignore those.  I think the general itemization goals of the classes are:

**Marksman**

* Goal: Deal the most amount of sustained damage possible (primarily through autoattacking)
* _Stats to aim for_
 * Attack Damage, Attack Speed, Critical Chance/Damage (because they all multiply together for increased DPS) 
 * Armor Penetration (usually % as Marksmen are often only able to safely attack tanks first, and are best suited to taking them down due to their sustained damage, but flat is fine or better if no one is stacking armor)
* _Stats that are useful but not required_
 * Lifesteal (to last longer, does not directly increase damage)
 * Movespeed (helps positioning/kiting and general map movement, etc)

**Assassin**

* Goal: Take out a single, priority target quickly (primarily through a combo of skills with a few auto attacks and skills that let them get away)
* _Stats to aim for_
 * Attack Damage
 * flat Armor Penetration.
* _Stats that are useful but not required_
 * Cooldown Reduction (Getting more combos off is useful, but your _primary_ goal is to kill in one combo.)
 * Movement Speed (You will generally be trying to flank, but move speed is always useful for map movement, etc)

With those in mind, you can see why the normal builds are _supposed to be_ something like (in no particular order):

**Marksmen**

* One or both of {{item:3031}} {{item:3508}} 
* One or occasionally two of {{item:3087}} {{item:3046}} {{item:3085}} {{item:3094}} 
* {{item:3006}} 
* One of {{item:3033}} {{item:3036}} or one of the flat penetration items if there is not much armor being built.
* One or occasionally two of {{item:3153}} {{item:3072}} {{item:3812}} {{item:3139}} 

If a further defensive item is needed, it can fill the last slot.  Otherwise expect two of one of the above.  Obviously, this is a generalization that applies to Marksmen with little to no ability damage.  The flat armor penetration comes in where there starts to be a higher percentage of non-scaling ability damage compared to basic attack damage.

To your point about wanting to build flat damage items, I think there are a lot of factors to consider.  In theory, the 2.5 AS 100 AD and 1.0 AS 250 AD builds have the same DPS, but the issue is how reliably you can get each of those attacks off.  In reality, AS has very non-linear effects on your damage, where you either get another attack off or you don't.  Also, team comps must be considered.  If you have to be too wary of an assassin or mage, you will have less opportunity to get attacks off, so you need to make each one count.  Big damage numbers are also funner to see, regardless of if they give the optimal DPS.  Crit as a stat has a reliability issue until you can build a lot of it, which makes it a weaker stat early.

**Assassin**
(I don't play assassins, so I could be way off, but these are what I would expect.)

* Boots of choice. I expect {{item:3009}} or {{item:3117}} but could see a defensive boot, if needed
* Some combination of {{item:3147}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3156}} {{item:3074}} {{item:3071}} {{item:3812}} 
* Defensive or semi-defensive items, if needed.

There are alternative builds where assassins take {{item:3031}} and/or {{item:3508}} for the extra burst from the criticals, but these are risky, because your burst now partly relies on RNG, and less effective since the removal of crit from Ghostblade.

Personally, I think truly ranged assassins, as opposed to the similar burst mages, would be a bad idea and thus do not need to be considered in this discussion.  I feel most assassins (AP and AD) are too safe already, but that's less itemization and more kit and probably my general distaste for playing against them.
